title: A Hilarious, Action-Packed Sequel Done Right
content: I recently re-watched Deadpool 2, and I must say, the movie still holds up brilliantly. From the direction to the special effects, everything about this film is crafted with precision, making it one of the most entertaining superhero movies to date. This time around, I paid closer attention to various aspects of filmmaking, and I was genuinely impressed by how well-executed it was. Here's my detailed review breaking down why Deadpool 2 is a masterpiece in its genre.Direction: AmazingDavid Leitch, known for his exceptional work in action films, did a phenomenal job directing Deadpool 2. He managed to balance the over-the-top humor with the emotional depth of the story, giving us a film that not only entertained but also resonated on a deeper level. Leitch's direction captured the essence of Deadpool - the crass, sarcastic, and hilarious anti-hero - while also bringing heart to the narrative. His ability to handle intense action sequences with clarity and precision was outstanding. Every scene felt purposeful, whether it was an explosive fight or a heartfelt moment.The pacing was spot-on, ensuring the audience never felt bored. Leitch's direction also allowed the humor to flow naturally without it ever feeling forced. It's a tough task to keep the humor fresh in a sequel, but he managed to do it perfectly. The blend of chaos and emotion in Deadpool 2 is what makes it a standout sequel.---Writing: GoodThe writing in Deadpool 2 was sharp, witty, and full of meta-humor, exactly what you'd expect from a Deadpool movie. Rhett Reese, Paul Wernick, and Ryan Reynolds did an excellent job in crafting a story that didn't just feel like a cash-grab sequel. They managed to build on the first film's success while introducing new elements that kept it fresh and exciting.The screenplay cleverly balanced humor, action, and emotion. The film didn't shy away from breaking the fourth wall, and those moments were among the funniest. The jokes about the X-Men universe, other superhero franchises, and pop culture references were brilliant. However, the most impressive part was how the writers seamlessly introduced heavy emotions, especially in Deadpool's personal journey of loss and redemption.The dialogue was incredibly clever, and Deadpool's sarcastic humor never got old. The banter between Deadpool and Cable, Deadpool and Domino, and the whole X-Force team was gold. It's rare to find a script that makes you laugh, cry, and cheer all at the same time, but Deadpool 2 nailed it.---Acting by Cast: GreatThe casting in Deadpool 2 was impeccable, and the performances were equally impressive. Ryan Reynolds once again proved that he was born to play Deadpool. His charisma, comedic timing, and ability to make the audience emotionally invested in his character were incredible. Reynolds didn't just play Deadpool; he was Deadpool.Josh Brolin as Cable was another highlight of the film. His portrayal of the time-traveling, no-nonsense soldier was intense and grounded. Brolin brought depth to Cable, making him a relatable character despite his tough exterior. His chemistry with Reynolds was off the charts, and their contrasting personalities made for some of the film's funniest and most intense moments.Zazie Beetz as Domino was a scene-stealer. Her cool, laid-back approach to the role and her chemistry with the rest of the cast were fantastic. Her character's superpower - luck - was hilariously and brilliantly portrayed, adding a unique dynamic to the action scenes. The supporting cast, including Julian Dennison as Firefist and Morena Baccarin as Vanessa, also delivered strong performances.---Original Music: GoodThe original music in Deadpool 2 was surprisingly effective. While the film leaned heavily on popular songs for comedic effect, the original score by Tyler Bates provided the necessary intensity and emotion in the right moments. The music complemented the film's tone, shifting from humorous to serious without feeling jarring.The use of music in action sequences was particularly clever. For instance, the ironic use of Celine Dion's Ashes in the opening credits was both hilarious and strangely fitting. The soundtrack kept the energy high throughout the film and added another layer of entertainment.---Cinematography: GoodJonathan Sela's cinematography in Deadpool 2 was remarkable. The visual style of the film was sharp, colorful, and immersive. The camera work during action sequences was fluid, making the combat scenes easy to follow while still delivering high-impact action.Sela captured the essence of Deadpool's world perfectly - gritty yet vibrant. The use of dynamic camera angles during fight scenes, slow-motion shots, and creative framing for comedic moments showcased Sela's mastery. The film's visual language was a significant contributor to its overall entertainment value.---Editing: GoodThe editing by Dirk Westervelt, Craig Alpert, and Elísabet Ronaldsdóttir was tight and effective. Given the film's fast-paced nature, the editing had to be sharp to keep the energy flowing, and it certainly delivered. The comedic timing in Deadpool 2 relied heavily on the editing, and the team managed to hit the mark every time.The action sequences were cut in a way that maximized the impact without causing visual confusion. The transitions between humor and drama were seamless, ensuring the audience stayed engaged throughout the runtime. The editing team deserves immense credit for maintaining the film's momentum from start to finish.---Casting: GoodThe casting department did an excellent job in assembling a diverse and talented cast. Bringing in Josh Brolin as Cable and Zazie Beetz as Domino was a stroke of genius. Both actors fit their roles perfectly and added significant value to the overall story.The choice to expand the X-Force team, albeit briefly, was also brilliant. Each character brought a unique dynamic to the group, making their brief but hilarious existence memorable. The casting team ensured that the chemistry between actors was natural, which elevated the overall quality of the film.---Costume Design: GoodThe costume design in Deadpool 2 was on point. Deadpool's suit retained its iconic look while being slightly upgraded for better functionality. Cable's futuristic armor looked incredible and added to his menacing persona. Domino's sleek and stylish costume perfectly complemented her character's laid-back nature.The team also did a great job with the X-Force members' costumes, ensuring each character looked unique and memorable. The attention to detail in costume design was evident and contributed to the overall visual appeal of the film.---Sound Department: GoodThe sound design in Deadpool 2 was excellent. The film's high-octane action required precise sound effects, and the sound department delivered. Every punch, explosion, and gunshot felt impactful. Additionally, the sound design for Deadpool's healing process and Cable's futuristic technology was particularly impressive.The dialogue was crisp and clear, allowing the comedic timing to land perfectly. The sound mix maintained a perfect balance between dialogue, background score, and sound effects, ensuring a seamless viewing experience.---Special Effects and Visual Effects: AmazingThe special and visual effects in Deadpool 2 were nothing short of phenomenal. The action sequences were packed with high-quality VFX, especially during the scenes involving Cable's technology, Domino's luck-based powers, and Deadpool's healing abilities.The CGI for Colossus was also incredibly detailed, making him feel like a real, tangible character rather than just a visual effect. The visual effects team did a commendable job in enhancing the film's over-the-top action while maintaining a grounded visual style.---Stunts: GreatThe stunt work in Deadpool 2 was mind-blowing. David Leitch, with his background in stunt coordination, ensured the action sequences were top-tier. The hand-to-hand combat, gunfights, and large-scale action set-pieces were all executed with incredible precision.The film's stunt team deserves major praise for creating thrilling and memorable action sequences that elevated the film's overall impact. Deadpool's chaotic fighting style, Cable's tactical combat, and Domino's effortless action all stood out.---ConclusionRewatching Deadpool 2 reminded me why I loved it so much the first time. It's rare to find a superhero film that perfectly blends humor, action, and heart without compromising any aspect. David Leitch's direction, Ryan Reynolds' charismatic performance, and the film's sharp writing made it an unforgettable experience.From the flawless special effects to the brilliant stunt work, Deadpool 2 stands as a prime example of how a sequel should be made. It expanded the story, introduced compelling new characters, and maintained the spirit of its predecessor.For anyone who enjoys a mix of gut-busting humor, intense action, and genuine emotion, Deadpool 2 is an absolute must-watch.

title: I think the studio got involved
content: The first Deadpool was great. It was not the first superhero film rated R, despite what people claimed, but it was a breath of fresh air nonetheless. It was foulmouthed, uncompromising, gory beyond belief and aimed purely at adults. Immature adults, admittedly, but still adults.So, does the sequel hold up? Well, yes and no. It has several good things going for it, but at the same time it feels a lot safer, a lot more meticulous, a lot less pure in its approach.The good things first. Ryan Reynolds is still living his dream with this character and it shows. Deadpool might not be as unleashed as he was in the first film, but he's still a blast to be around and a constant source of laughs. In fact, the cast in general is very good in my opinion. Josh Brolin as Cable, especially. Intimidating, scary and a total badass, yet fitting in perfectly with the rest of the characters, who for the most part are more about quips and body part jokes.Though I will say that the movie did not have enough Domino (Zazie Beetz) in it. Huge missed opportunity. Hopefully she will return in the next film.The action scenes were also good, although lacking that flair seen in the original. The humour worked, the dialogues were fun and the plot was not bad.And yet it is the plot, or rather the story, that's the biggest problem. Mainly the fact that there's too much of it. And that's not usually something to complain about. But let's be honest here. We go into a Deadpool movie for the gore, for the fourth-wall breaking, for the adult humour, for the utter disregard for cinema conventions. And this thing has all of those, but nowhere near as much as the original. Instead it actually tries to make us care, to get emotionally invested. It succeeds, funnily enough, but it's still questionable that it even tried in the first place.So, is the film worth a watch? Sure, if you liked the first one. This will give you your fix, no problems. And who knows, perhaps you'll even like the fact that the Merc with the Mouth makes you have the feels.

title: A Dead On Sequel
content:
Deadpool movies are so hard to review. It's not because their super complex, thought provoking, or even artistic symbolism, but it's more due to the fact of balancing ridiculous antics with serious hero quality. With the first movie being a breath of fresh air to the massively stuffed superhero movie genre, the sequel had a lot to live up to for pleasing the fanbase once more. After one of the most amazing advertisement campaigns to date, did this movie break the fourth wall of entertainment once again? Robbie K here to do his best to help you with your movie viewing pleasures. Let's go!Movie: Deadpool 2Director:
 David Leitch
Writers:
 Rhett Reese, Paul Wernick 
Stars:
 Josh Brolin, Ryan Reynolds, Morena BaccarinLIKES:Acting: Given all of Ryan Reynolds ups and downs, the young actor shines so well in the reboot version of Deadpool. His sass from previous comedy stunts (like Two Guys and A Girl) mixed with his physique/delivery of superhero, leads to a well-developed lead who carries the movie heavily on his costume equipped shoulders. Brolin comes in again as the villain, bringing his grit to a less CGI rendered height that works well to offset the hyper, ADHD like energy of Deadpool and with it comes great comedic banter. Much of the supporting cast nails their roles well too, capable of dropping lines and rocking CGI stunts.Domino: Of all of these though, Domino was my favorite character. In the age of rising female heroes, Domino is a well-developed character who brings so much to the weird table this film sets. Zazie Beetz really shines in this movie as a female partner in crime to counter the crazy of Deadpool. A great character who has a quirky power, this "lucky" girl brings bite to fight Deadpool's humor, decent skills with a weapon, and surprisingly some enlightened looks at life that bring some zing to the movie. This character was a fantastic addition to the movie that should help expand the audience.Story: A Deadpool comic is often not the most developed in the story department, and given the direction of the cinema... one never knows how a sequel story will end up. Happily, I can report that this sequel did a nice job in the story department, managing to bring a decent plot that helps our characters evolve yet sticking close to the humor vibe of the movie. It's nice to see a ridiculous character grow, but still stick to the core qualities and Deadpool 2 did a much better job than I could imagine.Special Effects: Deadpool's ridiculous stunts means needing to find some way to make the impossible, possible on the screen. Hat's off, or in this case masks off, to the department who made all the bouts, mutants, and futuristic technology come roaring to full force to immerse you into the action. Speaking of which,Action: The action of Deadpool 2 is a mixed bag for me, but there are plenty of components that worked well with me. At the front line, are a number of bouts that have that chaotic, adrenaline fueled themes to it, mixed with snarky comments and unrelenting jokes that keep things fun, exciting, and a great opener. Seeing the moves, they choreographed/crafted, showed promise for some epic finales to come, always a good idea to cast the net and get them caught up early right. More on that later.Comedy: In truth, the strongest weapon in Deadpool's arsenal is the comedy that this film is drenched in, and by drenched I mean caught in a deluge. This sequel picks up where the last left off and with it comes a cornucopia of styles all hectically crashing together in a giant abstract masterpiece. Nothing is safe from Deadpool's adulteration, as the red garmented maniac brings vulgarity, ridiculous finishes, pokes at stories, comics, movies (including the franchise itself), and of course slapstick that transitions to so much more. I kept laughing my head off in this movie and loved the writing, cleverness, and of course mid-credit scene that victoriously finishes the movie off and delivers the answer to the wishes and prayers of the fan base. So, so good.DISLIKES:Over the top moments: Deadpool I know is all about breaking the 4th wall on just about everything he can. And certainly, in this installment, the writers did their best to break that mold as often and intense as possible. Given the laxer ratings, Deadpool 2 shows no qualms with crossing the line. Primarily the cursing, Deadpool 2 doesn't know when to quit in terms of vulgar cursing and certainly goes down inappropriate avenues I didn't particularly enjoy. A minor one at best, be warned that anything is possible with a mad mercenary.Comedic Stints Go on and on: Like this review, Deadpool's comedic banter sometimes treks on for too long. Those liking to see two smart alecks duke it out in a battle of insults, fake outs, and sarcasm for minutes on end will be delighted with the writing of this movie. I admit I did like it at first, but near the end this ploy had soon started to wrinkle like Wade's face.Action: While I certainly liked the action for much of the movie, I can't help but admit I was a little disappointed as well. Sure, the humor is awesome, the inappropriate battle moves fit well, and it felt like a Deadpool sequence come to life with little to no punches pulled. Yet, I'm still spoiled on some of Marvel's glorious cinema wars and had hoped we'd get some match ups to give them a run for its money. The epic climactic fight didn't quite have the on the edge, clap in your seat, scream in excitement epic fights that the trailers had hinted at. Those moments were fly-overs in an extended montage.Predictable: My buddy is right in saying that the movie certainly goes a different route than presented in the trailers. However,... the movie (perhaps as a stunt itself), dropped too many hints to lead you down the path to the answers that awaited. I was able to figure out all the twists with ease, and not have my mind blown as I thought it would. Another small dislike, but hey got to be honest at times.Character use: The trailers promoted the heck out of X-Force, making sure that we got our eye fill on just about every angle of Deadpool's own team to rival the goody two shoes X-men. And while the characters got their time to shine in comedy moves, their overall contribution to the film was cheated out in my opinion. Maybe that's what the comics have done, or perhaps it was a brilliant comedic ploy. However, don't promote characters so heavily if you are going to dilute them so much. Even his fellow mutants from Xavier's got a bit of underplay, another example of too many pieces leading to sacrifices being required to not make the film too long.The Verdict:Truth is I loved Deadpool 2 and while I had some issues, (which are pickiness of course), the movie accomplishes the goals of being a comedic spoof of superhumans that brings that bite to eat we hungered for. It's fast paced, it's witty, and it still keeps the story going on a level I didn't expect and this provides the breath of fresh air again that the first one did. Still, it's not a perfect movie for me and I still hope to get some more action and character usage in the next installment should Disney not limit Fox's creativity on it. Worth a trip to the theater? Absolutely, though be warned that the movie is not designed for younger audience members, those with weak constitutions to blood, violence, and vulgarity, or those not ready to step over the abyss into craziness.My scores are:Action/Adventure/Comedy: 9.0
Movie Overall: 8.5

title: Funnier, filthier, and a crotch riot
content:

After the slow rocky start, you will be served up heaping piles of melodrama. Self-discovery. Trippy sequences, and Josh Brolin skulking in the background. They're not essential to move the franchise along, but they are hilarious and worth the wait.As a comedy, is were Deadpool 2 surpasses the original, dispelling the curse of sequels being god awful and ultimately so terrible they are forgotten. You may be annoyed at first, but like its star, Deadpool 2 will irritate you until you're a slave to the rhythm.

title: Deadpool 2
content: Sadly, this "Deadpool" adventure finds itself just a little too closely drawn into the "X-Men" franchise, and as such is not a patch on the first film. That said, there is still plenty of action and irreverent humour. "Wade" (Ryan Reynolds) messes up a hit and the survivor tracks him down and does for his love "Vanessa" (Morena Baccarin). He is now desperate and even has a go at suicide before "Colossus" puts Humpty Dumpty together again and takes him to the X-mansion to recuperate. Meantime, things are getting quite lively at a mutant re-education centre and it falls to "Wade" to try and keep the irascible young mutant "Firefist" (Julian Dennison) from the grasp of the pursuing "Cable" - a time travelling cyborg creation (Josh Brolin) who has the kid firmly in his sights. There are plenty of set piece, and amusing, scenarios but somehow this just isn't so funny as the first film. The originality has been subsumed into, and largely cuckolded by, the Marvel-verse and there are far too many other characters distracting from the potency of the "Deadpool" persona. It's becoming just a little too conformist and that defeats the purpose. Still, it's entertaining and Reynolds delivers some really pithy and observational one liners; makes several swipes at the social media generation and of course, makes sure that Brolin's mother-in-law features regularly as "Yentl". I really hope "Deadpool 3" reverts back to the stand-alone format, I would hate for this to just become another "X-men" adjunct.

title: Clever script turns the breaking of the fourth wall into a story

And they loved this broken 4th wall toy so much all else became insignificant. But since Ryan Reynolds has tons of charisma, and Morena Baccarin isn't short on the stuff too, it worked.We could say this is mostly true of the sequel, but it's done in a much more deliberate manner. It's as if the kids learned how to play with this toy. So despite of the fact that we rarely come across any real character in this movie. That is, we do see many cartoons passing by on the screen, most of them don't really matter, at least not in Deadpool's mind, and since the entire story is being told through his eyes we only see them as cartoons, even if Colossus gets a fair amount of screen time, he never grows into a fully developed character, others don't even get that much, passing as another short gag in the script. In fact only the talent of Josh Brolin and Zazie Beetz creates a character where very little character is really written for them. And still it works. And it works better than it did in the original installment. Because it's done thoughtfully, it shows what one can do with complete creative freedom if one keeps his sense of boundries and limitations, and understands the nature of the media.I only wish the writers of Avengers Infinity War had half the sense of Rhett Reese and Paul Wernick who wrote this with Ryan Reynolds. It would've made it into a much better movie too.

And they all get to be memorable in other ways as well. While I'll admit that the larger cast worried me, they gave everyone the right amount of screen time. With nearly all major scenes and jokes revisited or redone in some way(since they worked the first time), it's noteworthy and impressive that they're greater here. With few exceptions. The franchise building, though the marketing can make it seem obtrusive and excessive, is handled well. I can't wait to see more of Domino(Beetz, an inspired choice).This has a lot of strong language and bloody, gory violence. It's also frequently offensive, crossing the lines of what's politically correct. I recommend this to any fan of DP. 8/10

title: Wait. We Still Have Cable in the Future?
content: Usually I save this to the end, but just like the two Deadpool movies, we must operate all over the timeline: DON'T WAIT UNTIL THE END OF THE CREDITS; THERE IS NOTHING THERE.Now, the beginning of the end credits, absolutely. In fact, you MUST see those final scenes as the credits just begin as they (kinda 2) are thee best end credits scenes in any marvel movie EVER. They were absolutely the icing on the already best cake a Deadpool follow-up could've been.Admittedly, I was worried this would suffer from sequelitis and almost didn't see it despite loving the first one wholeheartedly. Mercifully, I woke up in enough time to catch a Dolby® screening and let me say this: Not as great as the original, but pretty damn close and extremely worth seeing.(Even) better soundtrack, absolutely hilarious jokes, inventive new ideas on the original's setup and excellent use of each character and their individual features are just a few of the many positives here. I was rolling in laughter for a grand majority and in awe on how they began with the same thread as the original and broke off with clever writing and directions - totally expanded the singular R-Rated Deadpool universe as if this was his own Avenger movie.Deadpool's on top of the world, or at least all-around it, with fighting "worse bad guys" with more maximum effort and maintaining his love life until tragedy strikes sending him on a journey of self-discovery, love and family. F that. It's just a fun kick-A adventure.The one thing that irked me though, was the pacing and length. Several scenes went on far too long even though some of those were meant for comedy and others were just poor choices. And you will feel every one of those 119 minutes. It's almost as if they felt this would bomb and they could never make another Deadpool movie. Hogwash. Of course, there'll be a third, fourth, etc.Can't wait to see this again and with the (now) knowledge that the movie feels too long at times, I'll probably enjoy it tons more the second time. There is so much in here to love and so many jokes I *know* I missed. Heck, I re-watched the original last night for the xxx'th time and caught one hilarious joke I must've missed the many times I've seen it before.ABSOLUTE recommendation. Really need to see the first one, but...nope, you must see the first one. But, hey, I gave that one 4½/5 stars so you really can't go wrong.***Final thoughts: While I began with the warning not to stay to the very end credits as there's nothing there, I will say the music choices all the way to the very end were worth it. I already loved the soundtrack, but it actually improved with the songs they played while the credits rolled.

title: A fun movie, but a step down from the original and the third
content: Deadpool 2, especially now after the mega success of Deadpool & Wolverine and the ground breaking nature of the first Deadpool, is naturally, the red headed step child of the franchise. It's definitely not as good as either of those movies, and it's not one I'd honestly find myself coming back to, but it's certainly not a bad movie.I think it expands pretty well upon the Deadpool universe in fun and exciting ways, giving us way more characters and finally touching upon the "human-mutant conflict" that the X-Men series is known so well for. The new cast of characters we meet are overall pretty good; especially Zazie Beets as Domino and Josh Brolin as Cable (although, as a big fan of the character, I couldn't help but feel they copped out a bit with his look).There are - surprisingly - quite a lot of story threads here. We have the loss of Vanessa, the "evil" version of the School for Gifted Children, the prison for mutants, Cable and time travel, X-Force, Colossus trying to get Deadpool to join the X-Men. Unfortunately, they don't all receive enough attention and it does lead to the film feeling a bit rushed in the end.I honestly think this movie is funnier than the original Deadpool, especially as I feel Reynolds' take on the character works the best when he's playing off of other people, and there's less cringe inducing pop culture references and 2010s era improv riffing than in the original.But, there is something special about that FIRST appearance of the character and the low budget nature of the movie; that is was scaled back and more character focused, that I think works better, overall.(The original was not low budget by any objective means, just compared to the superhero movie extravaganzas we'd become used to in 2016, it felt a little cheap in comparison)The action sequences are also pretty enjoyable, especially the chase involving Cable and Domino, but I can't help but feel the ending was also a bit of a letdown given the promise of Juggernaut being involved. (Also, we need to acknowledge a fully CG version of the character just did not work as well as Vinnie Jones, could they not have brought him back?)This isn't a bad movie by any means, it's quite a lot of fun, but something about it just screams "interregnum" you know? Not that we were aware of it at the time, but it's pretty clear that the X-Men as a franchise were a bit directionless in 2018 (and especially so after X-Men: Dark Phoenix), and this movie feels a bit of the same as well.

title: Less is more
content:
Let's start by saying that I loved the first Deadpool when it came out in theatres! I went to watch it with a whole bunch of friends and laughed more times than I could count. After seeing it a few more times, and of course also as a result of growing up, I could say that some things about the film where a little childish maybe (the overdose of sexual humor) but it was still a fun and original movie none the less! So naturally I was excited for the second one...and beyond all expectations...I really didn't like it that much.Let's start off positive, pretty much all the characters are great. Ryan Reynolds is great as Deadpool, Colossus is a fun presence as well as Cable and Domino are two very nice additions to this universe. There's one big twist somewhere in the middle that I LOVED, the action is very well done, the acting is good, the movie has a great tempo behind it and last but not least, the credits scenes are hilarious!So what happened? Well let's start by saying that it tries way too much at being as good as the first one. The method of narration is pretty much exactly the same, so it comes of as repetitive. The humor is once again good, but there are WAY too many times that it just doesn't work. I usualy don't mind pop culture references when they're done well, but here they just come out of nowhere and don't always fit in the moment. Another thing about the humor that didn't always work is that way too much of it is in your face. There's a scene where one person continiously says that a certain power of another person is absolutely useless while cette person is actually demonstrating to us that that power isn't useless. It was way too obvious what they where trying to do and I didn't find it funny.
The character of Cable is very cool and played well, but his introduction in this movie is extremely rushed, it almost felt like a bad Terminator movie at times, but luckily his character did improve. Another thing is the character of Firefist who is extremely inconsistent. This person changes his mind constantly during the movie that I found it very difficult to care for him, and the fact that this person plays a major part in the movie isn't that good.This movie was a mixed bag for me.
The action is great, the cinematography is very good, most of the acting is good, there are some very fun references and a good portion of the humor is well done.
On the other hand it does try way too hard at being like the first one, it feels very rushed at times, some characters are pretty difficult to follow and the other half of the humor is either way too much in your face or it just doesn't fit in the moment.It's a fun movie to go and see with your friends on a Saturday night, but nothing more.
I give it a 6.7/10.

But then, finally, sweet release rushes over you as the movie finally starts, and it's as if you've taken a page from Paul Finch's book and studied the art of sexual tantric meditation because for the duration of the entire run time you feel pure, radiating sexual pleasure.I'm not even exaggerating, but I am narcissistically stroking my own ego by overindulging in my own mediocre writing abilities, but that's how you get the A's kids, you write a bunch of fluff and make it sound professional, and now I'm making slightly above minimum wage in an insurance office doing work I did not go to college for so it looks like all my hard work paid off. title: Big CGI fights coming up.
content: The Original cast from 'Deadpool' is back for another adventure. Hollywood firmly believes sequels must be 'bigger and better'. 'Deadpool 2' definitely is (much) bigger, but not better than its predecessor.'Deadpool 2' continues its trademark with vulgarity, profanity and gay jokes in abundance. Now add blasphemy to this. In this installment, Wade Wilson aka Deadpool becomes suicidal after a tragic incident. Colossus 'rescues' Wade and takes him to the Essex House for Mutant Rehabilitation - or simply the X-Mansion. Believing his fiancé wanted him to join the X-Men, he agrees to become a member.14-Year old mutant Russell aka Firefist causes major chaos and destruction at an orphanage owned by the X-Men. Russell accuses the Headmaster of abusing him, and wants revenge. Wade and Russell are taken to prison for their antics, and soon after mayhem ensues when a soldier from the future, Cable, is in pursuit of Russell.What follows, is plenty of over-the-top action and destruction. With the Deadpool movies being pure satire, I believe these overblown scenes are intentional as it mocks other superhero movies. The rude dialogue actually makes these over-the-top sequences funnier than it ought to be. There's also clever reference to other movies and actors. The action sequences are incredibly well done, and the fight sequences are fast and brutal.'Deadpool 2' definitely looks a lot more like part of the 'X-Men' franchise than 'Deadpool' did. Although more entertaining than expected, I still enjoyed 'Deadpool' more. The crazy credits at the beginning and end of the movie are hilarious!

title: Good Balance between Trailer vs Movie
content: I want to start by saying having watched all trailers for DP2 as they came out over the past few months, I was starting to worry a little bit of trailers spoiling the movie but was happy with final trailer still not revealing much. To my joy it turned out they managed to strike a very good balance in terms of trailer fulfilling their teaser function without making me feel "yea we can skip this part of the movie, trailers got it covered".It is not a masterpiece of a movie, but going to Deadpool with that expectation is no different than riding merry-go-round for adrenaline. Deadpool 2 successfully delivers its promise of being an action packed mockery of superhero genre.The way it can go the lengths regular superhero movies can not dare go allowed the movie to accomplish some unique story twists and action scenes.Without spoiling anything there is a particular scene where Deadpool and Cable handshake, and that scene alone is worth the movie ticket.Plus kudos to Reynolds for the after credits scene.

title: A crude, visually appealing sequal.
content: This movie was the sequal that we didn't need, but needed. Alot of laughs and dramatic moments, doesn't gelo the really off pacing.

title: Just as good, if not better, than the first
content: I'll keep it short and sweet. If you liked the original Deadpool movie, then you'll love this. I was laughing almost the entire time and the rest of the people in my theater were, too.

title: Joke is on us
content: For every 10 min of "jocular" conversation, there is 2 min of story. And the story is nothing which you haven't seen before. Few jokes bring out a smile or laughter, but eventually the biggest the joke is made by director on us, with this lazy writing and weak story.If you care for your time, just watch DP 1

title: Movie was outstanding as it should be but......
content: Took my kids cause well the love Deadpool anyway they didn't get some of the jokes especially one eyed willy and my 13 year old left wanting more. He said the last part was his favorite and adding in the larger kids was crazy. So hopefully next time they can fix the punch lines and the old school jokes. Other then that I'm 36 and I loved it.

title: Better then the first! & that's saying something!
content: This movie has heart and pain and anger and redemption and it's funny as hell! It really made me think about all these kids shooting up these schools because of all the pain their carrying! And how one person could save them if someone just cared enough! I walked out of the theater and there was just 10 students shot in a Texas high school and it's weird to get hope from a DeadPool movie but that's what it gave me! I loved this film it's deeper and smarter then they want you to think it is! And that Celine dion song kicks ass! See this film!

title: it was ok
content: I gave it a 7 because they put a lot of effort/money into production value but other than that this movie is forgettable. I doubt it will me anymore memorable than most of the other marv/DC comic movies.

title: Funny but not annoying.
content:
Deadpool 2 is exactly what you've expected it to be from watching the first film. The jokes are great, they're original, funny but most importantly, not annoying. Most films with this much jokes are too annoying because they are trying too hard to fit a joke into every scene.
The music is also great as expected, most of them being classic songs that everyone should know like: "Take On Me" and others.
Story-wise however, the story is definitely lacking and doesn't make sense at some points, but what did you expect? I went to the cinema knowing that I just want the attitude and sarcasm of Wade Wilson and the music.

title: Good sequal
content: Good film as even if you don't get the movie references (like myself), it's still funny!

title: Worth the wait
content:
I went into the movie hoping it wouldn't be a lame attempt to cash in on the popularity of the first one. It definitely wasn't. As Reynolds himself said, the solo formula isn't good for more than a couple movies. Though they pushed it on the sequel it still worked. Mainly because there were so many twists in the movie.
Every time I thought it was getting too serious (I mean really, are looking for serious in a Deadpool movie), they threw a little twist and left you thinking, Ok, what's next?
The action was good, the humor was just as raunchy, and actually pretty topical without being to hipster.
Lots of making fun of himself, and others, throughout the movie.
In short, it was exactly what I expected, and wanted, from a Deadpool sequel.
The post credits scene was almost worth the price of admission by itself.

title: Not as good a DP1
content: I felt this was just a series of jokes strung together to make a movie. There was no gripping underlying story like the first one had. Most of the jokes were funny. I've never been a fan of TJ Miller and found nothing he did in the movie very funny. Reynolds was great as usual and Josh Brolin was good as well. But the lack of a story really set this apart from the first one for me.

title: Boring
content: I was laughing so hard with the first Deadpool. But this one, I was finding myself wanting to take a nap. Wasn't funny at all. Save your money, and just take a nap at home. I gave it 2 stars because I laughed once.

title: Best movie of 2018
content: When I saw this film, I had high hopes that it would be good and it was! The only problems that I had with this film are that it gets a little bit slow at times but then it almost imeaditly bounces back and gets great! Some things that I love about this movie are that it is VERY meta and self-aware and the writers are excelent.

title: Better than the first one
content: Better than the first one. Really funny, dark humor, lots of action sequences, gore, romance, drama and the most sad moments i've watched in a lot of time. Many references to pop culture (OST as well) and Marvel, and it mocks on DC Comics and Warner Bros at least 4 times. The opening credits are a tribute to James Bond, really well done and performed by Celine Dion. Good performances of Domino, Rusell (the kid) and Cable.There are 2 mid-credit scenes; the second one is the best mid-credit scene of all times in cinema history.

title: Nothing new. I like what they did at end.
content: It's a good movie. Same stuff, funny, rude stupid jokes and crazy mad action. Story could have been a lot better. No spoilers but I like the ending. Overall not a bad movie.

title: Insanely clever
content: The script and storyline was made in a way that is impossible to get bored. Is an experimental way of a linear narrative, by going back and forth because he's dying all the time. Is so clever. Plus all the references of movies, music and pop culture that just makes it more relatable to the everyday life. And the diversity of the cast and the black humor made the movie so pleasent to watch. The actions are aggressive and it can get very explicit but that's the spark about Deadpool. Very good job.

title: all i can say is hes back
content: I went to see this not exactly knowing what to expect besides a whole lot of fun but let me tell ya it was fantastic maybe even better then before there was plenty of slick humor loads of action heart and humor one of the best movies of the year with a good message we can all take away from it see it

title: I must concur the obvious.. It sucked some.
content: I try not to get my hopes up on sequels, as most sequels really fall short of their original. But I hoped this would be different. The opening minutes set the pace of the rest of the movie, just minus some humor, story line and the ability to keep you with the movie. I will say they tried a new angle to the character and gave him a heart. But this is a man who has looked death in the face and laughed and had a snide comment for those near him.We were packed into a theater with 8 other viewers, and the lack of laughter says it all. If you are a diehard DP fan, then go see your guy. But if you have an option, wait till this is on TV or your favorite streaming system. I do not feel too bad as I got a free ticket to see it, but wish it could have been for another movie.Do not get me wrong, I enjoy DP and how he was brought to the screen by Ryan and Co. But this episode fell really short of its mark. Unless its mark was to just ride the tails of the first movie. The hype did not meet the expectations put out there, and I for 1, and probably not the last, was bummed about the story.

title: Not very good
content:
Deadpool 2 has its share of funny moments and action but there is so little in the way of plot that it's impossible to care what happens to anyone. What plot there is doesn't even really start until about 45 minutes into the movie. The first 45 minutes is like an extended prologue that should have been cut to a montage in the opening credits.
The best thing in this film was Domino, the female character whose superpower is that she's lucky. The other new characters are totally forgettable. Even the kid from Hunt for the Wilderpeople is wasted here. His character isn't likeable and doesn't even have any funny lines that I can remember.
There were lots of moments that were meant to be serious, but with the lack of any conflict these parts were just boring. And whenever it did get funny, it usually had nothing to do with the plot.
Overall this film is badly paced and structured, with a plot that's barely there.

title: Makes the original movie look like "The Room" by comparison.
content: This movie is absolutely fantastic. I was consistently entertained throughout the whole thing. The story is hilarious and clever. The characters are all well-acted and portrayed (except for Weasel). My only complaint is that the end credits scenes (while being some of the funniest scenes in the entire movie) kinda create some plot holes. I don't care because its really really funny, but I wanted to point it out.Every problem from the first movie is fixed. There is better action and effects and the plot is much better. There are a lot of strange camera angles and editing decisions, but nothing too bad.If you liked the first movie, you'll love this one.

title: Better than the first!
content:
Better story line. 
Amazing action. 
Fresh laughs. 
True to the original.A truly epic sequel!!

title: just fine
content: I admit I was attracted by the trailer that was so funny and its good box office. the scenes weren't incredibly interesting yet still okay. I knew there'll be Deadpool 3 in the future, not offensive, but then I won't go watch.

title: SO GOOD!!!!!
content: In this film Deadpool puts together a team to protect a teenage mutant from the time travelling cyborg Cable.This film is directed by David Leitch (Atomic Blonde). It stars Ryan Reynolds (Deadpool), Josh Brolin (No country for old men) and Julian Dennison (Hunt for the wilderpeople).First of all, this film is so watchable, typing up this review right now, I just want to go a nd watch it again. Secondly, Leitch brings his considerable talents to the franchise and was such a good choice to direct, after Tim Miller left. Leitch adds these almost effortless one shot fight scenes, that I simply couldn't get enough of. This film is laugh out loud hilarious, even funnier than the first film in my opinion. Ryan Reynolds never lets me down with his performance. But to me Domino (Zazie Beetz) and Cable (Josh Brolin) are the stand out characters of this film.However, the story is nonexistent, and the CGI, especially at the end was really noticeable. Yes, I know it was made on a lower budget than other superhero films. But if you think about it Deadpool 2 was made on a budget of about $110,000,000, that is at least twice as much as the original Deadpools budget and yet the CGI still looks the same even with twice the budget.In my opinion, this film is better than the original. I personally believe that the first Deadpool film is ok, but this film is great and a must watch.8/10
